Subject: Re: [neat] Alternating loss functions for evolution
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=464818732; y=eVO_0IaomgEeWhS0pKw_81_WXwXELMxXdtdBcCm0cWa4aSAPVf9c

Content-Transfer-Encoding: quoted-printable
Content-Type: text/plain;
	charset=utf-8

> In most deep learning research that I have seen they compute the loss (an=
d gradients) for one task, then for the other. But they do it every iterati=
on for both, so it is quite similar to having one combined loss. (I am unsu=
re if this is how they train Bert, or if they train for one task first, the=
n the other.)
> 
> 

Yes, as you say, if you alternate that frequently they=
 are effectively one task .

> There are examples that are closer to what y=
ou describe, though! I am thinking of GANs, where you train your generator =
against a discriminator (which produces the loss) and after a certain amoun=
t of epochs this discriminator is updated, thus changing the fitness landsc=
ape for the generator. Do you think this would fit your definition?

Inters=
ting point. GANs are non-stationary, and thus the objective just change ove=
r time, so I agree they have a bit of the flavor of goal-switching. They ar=
e thus like Novelty Search in a sense. I still think they are qualitatively=
 different from QD algorithms that keep many fixed tasks and let solutions =
switch between them, but the difference is smaller between GAN and QD than =
QD and single-task optimization. 

> 
> By the way, I think your paper on m=
odularity and weight costs is fantastic, the biological implications are am=
azing!

Thanks! We are glad to hear that. 

> 
> 
> 
> 
> 


--Apple-Mail=_430D31D4-B9CC-4789-A4D1-C9EDEFD86AA2
